body:
Do you remember this moment? for me is the most passionate moment of League of Legends, so far I haven't seen anything of this magnitude after season 3.

Why is Riot watering down its game? Now a matches end at 20-25 minutes... even at 10 minutes when one side is super fed since the turrets are really weak and its so easy to snowball by Riot design. Riot is going for the lowest common denominator.

The game is either one stomp on one side or the other and it doesn't feel like even trying anymore. I used to never surrender and fight until the nexus is destroyed. But when you encounter a fed Darius or a fed Ryze and a team thats 1 whole rank below you or even unranked whats the point anymore? its impossible to outplay and they will only keep taking objectives until you lose. I surrender at 20 most of the times now, whats the point? 

Is this what Riot wants with its game? meaningless matches to cross fingers that you got the good premade? Is it true that the game has gone downhill since season 3?

Games are shorter the higher the elo and more onesided. I speak from watching streams, looking up statistics and personal experience.

and the fact that this person doesn't know that proves that ranking system is fine with dynamic queue at low elos. the only reason i couldn't say this is because i do not play at high elo. and i think anyone seriously playing league looks up statistics and watches streams. look at the avg game time in the lcs tho and look at how back and forth those matches are. they arent decided in the first 10 minutes at the professional level. we just cant reach our maximum potential without increasing our teamwork and dynamic queue allows for that. granted, i dont like it at the moment but in the future i think it will affect teamwork in our ranked games. do you disagree with my statement on dragon and its snowball potential?

Generally, the first team to get dragons is the team that keeps getting dragons, at least at higher elos. Because it is generally too risky to try to sneak drag or steal afterwards. And usually the team with the kill advantage gets the dragons, making them even more impossible to kill.

And just an FYI, I never give up in a ranked game, I never do. There is always a chance that the enemy will throw. It is just extremely rare. 

Also, the LCS matches are not that back and forth sadly. Sure, there may be one throw here and there but generally, it rarely results in a complete turn around for the losing team.

Especially if a team gets an inhib. Teams that get the first inhib of the game have a 90% chance of winning.
To be honest. I can't remember the last time I actually had fun with this game... Heck I barely even login anymore.

...the ever changing cycle:

Games last too long! 30+ min is too long for a game!

Games are too short! 20 min and it's already over!

Snowballing can be fun.
Long games with 10 total kills can also be fun.
Personally I like the 30-40 minute mark, past 40 is really dangerous, but knowing you lost/win in less than 20 minutes is ridiculous, getting into the game takes longer than that.

You do realize that in many single and team based games you can often tell who has the better chance of winning early on, especially if the two single / teams aren't actually equal in skill? It's not something new for LoL or anything.

"Chance" is the key word here. In previous seasons, even a team that is getting stomped can turn the game around with a clutch teamfight or baron steal. Now, with how snowbally the objective game gets, it's rather difficult to stage a true come-from-behind win without the enemy making a serious blunder or a series of blunders.

Name any team FPS, you'll find the same thing.

You just compared apples to fucking steak tips. If that sounds ridiculous, that's because it is. League is an ENTIRELY different kind of game than the examples you just gave. If you make a mistake in Street Fighter, your opponent does not gain a power advantage over you, whereas in LoL, fucking up and dying will lead to a gold and experience gain for your enemy which will translate into an eventual item advantage which will help your opponent farm/kill you even more effectively, and the snowball keeps going. Also, please give me your best estimate as to how long each round in a Street Fighter match lasts. Is 30 seconds a fair assessment? I'm honestly not entirely sure, as I know very little about the competitive scene there. Needless to say, not even close to how long a game of LoL lasts (even a short one) and therefore, mistakes will be substantially more impactful, as there is SUBSTANTIALLY less time to recover from them.

Also, it seems like you missed the point. We aren't comparing League to other games, we are comparing League as it exists today to League as it existed in the past. And it has changed a lot. Don't bring in other games that we may not even know about just to try to make a point. Especially if those games aren't MOBAs.

Dragon advantage snowballs. Literally everything in the game snowballs, and it has gotten to the point where it is VERY difficult to make a comeback. That's what's supposed to happen. If he doesn't land the flashbang, he shouldn't have a chance against someone who out-damages him in immediate range.
even with flashbang if one shot misses hes dead.

Completely gutted? Hardly.

Widowmaker, a sniper, was able to one-shot bodyshot kill three characters in the game (Un-meched D.Va, Tracer, and Zenyatta). Not only that, but her ability to quickly charge a shot made it incredibly easy for her to very quickly bodyshot many other characters to death. Basically she had a sniper's damage and range without the drawback of actually having to get head shots. The changes Blizzard made were simple and effective. They reduced bodyshot damage to 120 (so she no longer one shots those three characters) and made her scoping slightly slower. She still does good damage, has strong mobility, and is possibly in need of even more work. You saying she was "gutted" is a joke.

McCree? He was, across the board from professional to casual play, regarded as an unbalanced menace. With the damage on his Fan the Hammer he was able to successfully duel quite literally every hero in the game. Using his combo of Flashbang/Fan the Hammer/roll/Fan the Hammer he could 100 to 0 the majority of the cast before they even got a chance to properly react. How did they fix this? Without touching his roll or Flashbang they reduced his Fan the Hammer damage. They didn't nerf it into the ground, they just lowered it enough that McCree players actually have to hit all their shots from Fan the Hammer to get a reliable kill (not hard if you Flashbang first) and lowered the damage enough that a tank could ACTUALLY tank. Not only that, but they actually decreased his reload speed to compensate for the damage drop. Again, he's still perfectly viable.

The fact that you complain about these changes and call them "unbalanced" really only shows you either 1) don't play the game enough or 2) were really enjoying playing these unbalanced champs and are now salty that you actually have to learn some fundamentals to succeed on them.

Yes i played mostly them but not because they were easy wins or whatever. Mccree is a cowboy, there is literally no reason for him to not be played, and is a perfectly reasonable reason for him to be OP.
